On Wednesday 21 September 2005 15:20, Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Chris Dollin wrote:
> > It's always puzzled me why Java got this wrong (yes, I think "wrong"
> > is the appropriate term) when even C got it right. It means, for
> > example, that various strings cannot be constants.
>
> Au contraire. Java's right. C's wrong. In Java you know a \n is a
> linefeed. No if's, and's, or but's. 

I don't mind having a `linefeed` character. I do mind not having
a notation for `the end of the line, however it's supposed to
happen in this streamlike thing that I am writing down`.

> This means when you're writing or
> reading a protocol or network file format that specifies a linefeed, you
> know what you're getting. You can depend on it. 

That's fine and I have no quarrel with it. 

> In 2005 there is no good
> reason to change the line separator to match some imagined platform
> default.

I'm not asking for that. I'm asking for a notation for end-of-line;
it's not the same thing. You may have a case that such a thing
cannot plausibly be provided.

> All reasonable text editors can handle \r, \n, or \r\n. 

That depends on what you mean by "handle" and "reasonable". 
(I use a text editor which I suspect you would classify differently
than I would.) 

> Many
> protocols and file formats specify one or the other of these. For
> instance HTTP headers MUST be terminated with \r\n. \n and \r alone are
> incorrect (though many clients are liberal in what they accept). This is
> regardless of platform or OS.

Yes, that one has always puzzled me too.

> We live in a multiplatform, multi-OS, multilingual world. Platform
> defaults of all kinds are harmful. Data must not be tied to one type of
> computer or operating system. We need multiplatform, multilingual,
> multilocale data.

We live in a multiplatform world in which different platforms
have different conventions for what counts as a "line" in a "text
file". I'd prefer to be able to write a "text output stream" without
having to jump through hoops to separate one line from the next
in my text strings. Similarly I'd like to be able to read "lines"
from a "text file" without having to dither about how those lines
are separated.

Perhaps I'm just recklessly optimistic.

-- 
Chris "all the diodes down my left side" Dollin
The software engineer's song: "who knows where the time goes".
